title: Is it true that some people in the US don't believe in education? If so, why? - Quora
tags: Education in the United States of America

response.answer_text: The question is not whether they believe in education or don’t believe in education. That is the wrong question. The correct question is how do views differ on who should receive an education, and what type of education is appropriate. Examples: Back before slavery was outlawed, in some places educating a slave was against the law. At one time people only thought men should be educated & not women. At one time families didn’t think every child needed an education … most typically in rural or farming communities. Significant differences still exist today in what form of education is considered appropriate, which is the reason communities have private schools … some for gifted, some for inclusion of religious content, and some just because they don’t like what the public schools teach, or they don’t like the public schools hands-off attitude towards discipline [notably bullying], or any other reason.

There are some who are rather paranoid about indoctrination vs education. They believe that some great conspiracy is trying to brainwash children or even college students and so they oppose education unless it is they themselves who are doing the educating. There is no doubt that education can indoctrinate. But too often the problem is not a conspiracy trying to turn our children into communists or liberals or (whatever other thing people fear) but, rather, people fearing that their children will learn something that causes them to disagree with the beliefs of their parents. It is often the lack of education that indoctrinates. Sooner or later we have to trust educators to be trying to educate and students to be trying to learn. If we encourage our children to be open minded and to think critically we can overcome the problems of poor education and lack of education.

Not really, no. Although most people do believe that there are more important things like character, boldness, and “common-sense” (your ability to make decisions). But I’ve never met anyone (other than religious nut-jobs) who would say that there’s anything inherently wrong with education. We just don’t consider it the most important thing. For example, many parents don’t believe the primary purpose of school (K through 12) is education. They believe the primary purpose is to socialize their kids amongst their peers. I don’t know that I agree agree with that, but a lot of Americans do hold that view.

I don’t know of anyone who thinks all formal education is bad or pointless. At some point, everyone decides that further education is not worth the time, cost, and opportunity cost. You’d rather go out and get a job instead of more education. For some people, that’s in your teens. For others it’s at 18, after finishing (in the US) K-12 primary education. Some stop at 22 with a bachelor’s degree. Others continue to a masters or PhD. Side note, I think in the US, just over a third of all people complete a 4-year college degree. The rest either aren’t interested or would rather have wages now, not four years from now.

Donald Trump “loves the poorly educated” and wants to keep them that way. So does everyone who wants to take advantage of their ignorance. The rich and large corporations, ReTrumplicans generally, televangelists, …
